title: Pembrokeshire Coasteering Break
tagline: Two days of cliff jumping and coastal thrills in the birthplace of coasteering
highlights: TYF coasteering at the birthplace of the sport
suitableFor: Active couples or groups of friends who enjoy a physical challenge and aren't afraid of heights or cold water. Confident swimmers are essential.
notSuitableFor: Those with significant mobility issues, a fear of heights, or who are not comfortable swimming in the sea. Young children may find it too challenging.
packingEssentials: Sturdy footwear (old trainers are ideal for coasteering)
Change of warm clothes for after

stops.title: Coasteering at Abereiddy Blue Lagoon
stops.description: Experience coasteering where it was invented! TYF Adventure pioneered the sport here in 1986. Jump from cliffs into the stunning turquoise Blue Lagoon (a flooded slate quarry), explore sea caves, scramble across rocks, and swim in the Atlantic. All equipment provided including wetsuit, helmet, and buoyancy aid. Sessions tailored to group ability with jumps from 1m to 10m (all optional).

requirements.swimAbility: Must be able to swim 25m confidently

stops.insiderTip: The Blue Lagoon was a slate quarry until 1910 when a storm breached the sea wall. The turquoise colour comes from minerals in the rock. Book the morning session for calmer seas and better light for photos.

wetAlt.title: St Davids Cathedral Tour
wetAlt.description: Explore Britain's smallest city and its magnificent 12th-century cathedral. The cathedral sits in a hidden valley - stunning architecture and 1,400 years of history. Free to enter, guided tours available.

budgetAlt.title: Coastal Path Walk: Abereiddy to Porthgain
budgetAlt.description: Beautiful 2.5-mile section of the Pembrokeshire Coast Path. Dramatic cliffs, wildlife, and ends at Porthgain harbour for lunch. Free!

stops.title: The Sloop Inn
stops.description: Iconic harbourside pub in the picturesque former quarry village of Porthgain. Famous for fresh local seafood, crab sandwiches, and hearty pub classics. Book ahead for weekend lunches as it gets packed. Outdoor seating overlooking the harbour.
stops.insiderTip: The crab sandwich is legendary - caught locally that day. Arrive before 12:30 for a harbour-view table without booking.

alternative.title: The Shed Bistro (Porthgain)
alternative.description: More upmarket fish restaurant in the old harbour buildings. Excellent seafood platters. Booking essential.

budgetAlt.title: Beach picnic at Whitesands
budgetAlt.description: Pick up supplies from St Davids Food & Wine and picnic on Pembrokeshire's best surfing beach.

stops.title: Explore St Davids
stops.description: Britain's smallest city (population ~1,800) is a delight to explore. Visit the stunning 12th-century cathedral hidden in a valley, browse independent shops, art galleries, and cafes. The Bishop's Palace ruins are worth the entrance fee.
stops.insiderTip: The cathedral is hidden from the main square - walk down past the shops to discover it. Evensong at 6pm is beautiful and free.

wetAlt.title: Oriel y Parc Gallery & Visitor Centre
wetAlt.description: Modern gallery with exhibitions about Pembrokeshire's landscape and culture. Free entry, excellent cafe, and a great rainy day stop.

stops.title: St Davids YHA
stops.description: Modern eco-friendly hostel built from sustainable materials, a 10-minute walk from the city centre. Private rooms and dorms available. Self-catering kitchen, lounge with log burner, and bike storage. One of YHA's flagship properties.
stops.insiderTip: Book a private room with cathedral view if available. The communal kitchen is excellent for self-catering - there's a Coop in St Davids for supplies.

budgetAlt.title: Caerfai Bay Campsite
budgetAlt.description: Beautiful clifftop campsite walking distance from St Davids. Sea views from many pitches. Basic facilities but stunning location. Organic farm with small shop.

premiumAlt.title: Twr y Felin Hotel
premiumAlt.description: Contemporary boutique hotel in a converted windmill tower. Art-filled interiors, excellent restaurant, and spa. A proper treat.

stops.title: Sea Kayaking around Ramsey Island
stops.description: Paddle around the dramatic coastline near Ramsey Island, home to grey seals, porpoises, and rich birdlife. Suitable for beginners with a guided session. See sea caves, arches, and possibly seals hauled out on rocks. All equipment provided.

alternativeOperators.name: Thousand Islands Expeditions
alternativeOperators.description: Boat trips to Ramsey Island for wildlife watching if kayaking not preferred

stops.insiderTip: Ask your guide to take you into Cathedral Cave if conditions allow - it's like paddling into a natural amphitheatre. Morning sessions often have calmer seas.

wetAlt.title: Second Coasteering Session
wetAlt.description: If you loved yesterday's coasteering, book another session at a different location for variety. Try Preseli Venture at Solva for a different perspective.

budgetAlt.title: Ramsey Island Boat Trip
budgetAlt.description: Non-landing boat trip around Ramsey Island with Thousand Islands. See grey seals, porpoises, and seabirds without getting in the water. Great alternative if weather turns.

stops.title: Cwych Cafe (St Davids)
stops.description: Popular cafe in the centre of St Davids serving excellent coffee, homemade cakes, and light lunches. Welsh rarebit, soups, and local produce. Vegetarian-friendly.

alternative.title: Sampler (St Davids)
alternative.description: Tapas-style small plates and excellent wine. More of a treat for a longer lunch.

budgetAlt.title: St Davids Food & Wine + picnic
budgetAlt.description: Excellent deli with local cheeses, meats, and bread. Perfect for a beach picnic at Whitesands.

stops.title: Whitesands Beach Afternoon
stops.description: End your trip at Pembrokeshire's premier beach. Whitesands (Traeth Mawr) offers golden sand, excellent waves for swimming or surfing, and views to Ramsey Island. Surf hire available if you want to catch a wave. Blue Flag beach with lifeguards in summer.
stops.insiderTip: The beach cafe does excellent chips. If you're an early riser, this is one of the best sunrise spots in Wales - the sun comes up over the headland.

wetAlt.title: Cardigan Guildhall Market
wetAlt.description: If rain sets in, drive 30 mins to Cardigan for their excellent covered market. Local produce, crafts, and a great cafe.

standard.notes: Based on 2 adults, hostel accommodation, 2 activities

budget.notes: Camping, one paid activity, packed lunches

premium.notes: Boutique hotel, all activities, restaurant meals

knowBeforeYouGo.weather: Pembrokeshire has a mild but changeable maritime climate. Sea temperatures are cold (14-17°C in summer) but wetsuits make coasteering comfortable. Atlantic swells can make activities weather-dependent - operators will switch locations or reschedule if needed.
knowBeforeYouGo.traffic: The A40 can get congested, especially around Carmarthen. Allow extra time on summer weekends. St Davids parking is limited and fills quickly in peak season - arrive before 10am or use the Puffin Shuttle bus from Haverfordwest.
knowBeforeYouGo.booking: Coasteering and kayaking MUST be booked in advance, especially in summer. Same-day bookings are rarely possible. Book accommodation early for summer weekends - Pembrokeshire is extremely popular.
knowBeforeYouGo.fitness: Coasteering requires reasonable fitness, swimming ability, and a willingness to get fully immersed in cold water. All jumps are optional - you can climb down if you prefer. Sea kayaking requires moderate upper body strength but suitable for beginners.
knowBeforeYouGo.puffinShuttle: The Celtic Coaster (Puffin Shuttle) bus runs in summer connecting St Davids with key beaches and the coast path. Useful for linear walks. Runs late May to early September.
knowBeforeYouGo.seals: Grey seals breed on Pembrokeshire's beaches October-December. Keep your distance (at least 50m) if you see any - disturbing them is illegal and dangerous.

addDay.title: Add Skomer Island Puffin Trip
addDay.description: Extend your trip with a day trip to Skomer Island (April-July) to see the famous puffin colony. Boats from Martin's Haven, booking essential weeks in advance.

alternative.title: Surf Day at Newgale
alternative.description: Swap kayaking for a surf lesson at Newgale Beach - Pembrokeshire's longest beach with consistent waves. Newsurf and others offer lessons.

mapRoute.totalDriving: Approximately 45 minutes total over 2 days (excluding travel to/from Pembrokeshire)
